channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Afghan President, in Reversal, Backs U.N. Role to Settle Election Dispute
item.description: President Hamid Karzai’s comments revived the possibility that the international community might once more have a hand in the selection of a new leader for Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED

item.title: Bits Blog: Canadian Judge Says Google Must Remove Links Worldwide
item.description: The temporary order, granted last Friday by the Supreme Court of British Columbia, emerged from protracted litigation between two companies that were once closely connected.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Google has argued that following a global order by a Canadian court to remove specific search results could put in into conflict with laws of other countries.

item.title: Deep in the Amazon, an Isolated Village Tunes In the World Cup
item.description: The fevered grip of the world’s largest sporting event can be felt even in some of the most isolated areas of the rain forest, where outsiders seldom visit.
item.dc:creator: By JERÉ LONGMAN
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: The decks of the PP Maués were crisscrossed with hammocks for an overnight trip down the Amazon.

item.title: Spain, Stepping Back From Austerity, Plans to Cut Taxes
item.description: The government has approved plans to cut company and income taxes in 2015 and 2016 in a bid to bolster spending and investment.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: As Ukraine Announces Cease-Fire, White House Points Finger at Russia
item.description: The Obama administration said Moscow was continuing to covertly arm rebels in the eastern part of Ukraine, despite its denials.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ANDREW ROTH
item.media:description: Pro-Russian troops in tanks driving toward Donetsk on Friday.

item.title: Pope Condemns Legalization of Recreational Drugs
item.description: Pope Francis condemned the legalization of recreational drugs as a flawed and failed experiment as he lent his voice Friday to a debate that is raging from the United States to Uruguay.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Japanese Report Casts Doubt on Admission of Wartime Sexual Coercion
item.description: A new report questioned the factual accuracy of a landmark apology to women forced to work in military brothels in World War II, a finding that could worsen tensions with South Korea.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Lebanon Holds 17 in Assassination Plot; Possible Link to Iraq Rebels
item.description: Security forces arrested 17 men in two Beirut hotels on suspicion that they belonged to the Sunni militant group known as ISIS and were plotting to assassinate a prominent Shiite leader.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD and MOHAMMAD GHANNAM
item.media:description: Lebanese security forces surrounded the Napoleon Hotel in Beirut on Friday and detained 12 men.

item.title: Refugees at Levels Not Seen Since World War II
item.description: More than 51 million people have been displaced by violence around the world, according to the head of the United Nations refugee agency.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Syrian children at a refugee camp in eastern Lebanon on Thursday.

item.title: Number of French Jews Emigrating to Israel Rises Sharply
item.description: The number of French émigrés was four times higher in the first three months of the year than in the year-earlier period, in part because of a weak economy and anti-Semitism.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: A surveillance camera image of a man suspected of a deadly attack at the Jewish Museum in Brussels last month.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: The Latest Icon in Artistic Rebellion: A Cabbage
item.description: There’s a reason the Chinese authorities are not known for their sense of humor. They even stopped the artist Han Bing when he went to Tiananmen Square with the latest trendy object in the Chinese art world — a pet cabbage.
item.dc:creator: By DAN LEVIN

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: June 20
item.description: Students in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, praying for the safety of Indians kidnapped by militants in Iraq.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: School children in Ahmedabad, Gujarat praying for the safety of the Indians kidnapped by militants in Mosul, Iraq.

item.title: Top Shiite Cleric in Iraq Urges Inclusive Government
item.description: A statement by Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani also said his call to arms against the Sunni insurgency was an appeal to all Iraqis, not just Shiites.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani called on Iraq’s diverse political parties to move quickly to form a government.

item.title: In Hong Kong, an Unofficial Election Draws Beijing’s Ire
item.description: More than 350,000 Hong Kong residents voted Friday in a nonbinding referendum on how their next leader should be chosen. The Chinese government called it “illegal and invalid.”
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE, CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: Members of the group Occupy Central with Love and Peace, which organized an unofficial referendum in Hong Kong, before voting began on Friday.

item.title: At War Blog: Moments in Iraq Reporters Will Never Forget
item.description: As the country once again teeters toward sectarian warfare, we asked reporters from The New York Times — now on other beats, in other parts of the world — which of their stories from their time in Iraq have been resurfacing in their minds.
item.dc:creator: By NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:credit: Scott Nelson for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Iraqi boy at a destroyed roadside memorial commemorating children killed in 2005 by a car bomber.

item.title: India Ink: Court Allows Coca-Cola Plant to Reopen in Uttar Pradesh
item.description: A Coca-Cola production facility in Uttar Pradesh State that was forced to close earlier this month due to concerns over pollution will reopen after an environmental court ruled in the company’s favor on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Cans of Coca-Cola at a production facility in Greater Noida in the state of Uttar Pradesh.

item.title: As Child Migrants Flood to Border, U.S. Presses Latin America to Act
item.description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., on a visit to Guatemala, plans to highlight the dangers facing the children and the futility of their quest.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Workers in Iraq Staying Put, for the Moment
item.description: Chinese citizens based in the country’s south, which is less affected by the violence and where Chinese investment is concentrated, said that they felt safe for now and had no immediate plans to leave.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG
item.media:description: Workers at the Waha Oil Company in Wasit, southeast of Baghdad.

item.title: Turkish Officers Convicted in 2012 Coup Case Are Released
item.description: The officers were among 330 convicted in the “Sledgehammer” case, so called because of the code name of an alleged plot to destabilize the government.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan recently began discrediting military officers’ convictions.

item.title: U.S. Gives Thailand and Malaysia Lowest Grade on Human Trafficking
item.description: A State Department report released Friday ranks the two Southeast Asian countries with North Korea, Iran and Zimbabwe.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID MOLL

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Does Germany Need a New Flag?
item.description: Our black, red and gold banner doesn’t get out much, but it’s most useful as a cover for your car mirror during the World Cup.
item.dc:creator: By JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor : Egypt’s Sexual Violence
item.description: It doesn’t matter where you stand on the political spectrum — if you are a woman, your body is not safe.
item.dc:creator: By MONA ELTAHAWY
item.media:description: A mural on a wall in Cairo read ‘‘no harassment,’’ in Arabic.

item.title: Israeli Troops Kill Palestinian Teenager Protesting West Bank Arrests
item.description: The government forces were carrying out searches and arrests in a campaign to find three Israeli youths abducted a week ago.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: From an Indian Muslim’s Brush ...
item.description: Art, itself a form of worship, can spread truths where religions divide.
item.dc:creator: By BINA SHAH

item.title: In Chaos, Iraq’s Kurds See a Chance to Gain Ground
item.description: As the advance of Sunni militants shakes Iraq’s government, Kurds see an opportunity to move closer to their long-sought goal of independence.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the pesh merga, the Kurdish security forces in Iraq, at a checkpoint about 12 miles from Kirkuk, a city the Kurds now control after the Iraqi Army fled.
